item.gloss: Comely: 'Attractive, beautiful, handsome; graceful, elegant', OEDO.
Nonage: ‘The state of being under full legal age; minority', OEDO.
Amain: ‘Immediately’, OEDO.

Witnesses: godparents; term usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term 'witness' interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.

Delinquent: 'An opponent of the Parliamentary party in 17th-cent. England’, OEDO. [split:note] Syddall and Nesbitt's dispute over the living of Kirklington began in 1646 after William Clarkson (chaplain to Lord Ferdinando Fairfax) lost the living, according to Thornton because he preached against the Lord's Prayer: Book 3, page 35. Nesbitt began to petition for the living in 1645, but Syddall officiated in the church until 1649 without being instituted, despite orders from Parliament for Nesbitt's institution throughout 1646. Nesbitt finally took the living in 1649. See 'May 26 [1646]. Petition of Michael Syddall, praying for institution and induction to the rectory of Kirklington, in the Diocese of Chester', and 'July 31 [1646]. Petition of Philip Nisbett, minister of Kirklington, in the County of York', Journal of the House of Lords, vol. 8 (London: His Majesty's Stationary Office, 1767-1830), 331, 405.
Sequestration: 'Seizure of the possessions of a subject by the state', OEDO.

Witness: godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. Deflower: 'To deprive (a woman) of her virginity; to violate, ravish', OEDO.

Witness: godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
Stoop: 'A post, pillar', OEDO.

Causey: 'This word had several closely related meanings which all refer to raised ways, either across low-lying land subject to flooding or at the side of tracks used by pedestrians and horses', Yorkshire Historical Dictionary, https://yorkshiredictionary.york.ac.uk/words/causey.
Standing: 'Hesitating', OEDO.
Breech: 'The hinder parts of a beast', OEDO.
Debauched: 'Depraved or corrupt in morals', OEDO.
Hie: 'To advance', OEDO.

Providence: 'In full providence of God (also nature, etc.), divine providence. The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance', OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).
Thrice: 'Very, highly, greatly, extremely', OEDO.
Fraught: 'To store, supply, furnish with (a stock of); to equip', OEDO.
